elements.content: Three different N,N′-donor ligands with Zn­(NO3)2­·6H2O and two different dicarboxylates, flexible succinate (suc) and rigid fumarate (fum) afforded six different metal–organic frameworks (MOFs). Among the N,N′-donor ligands, one bent 1,4-bis­(3-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene (3-bpdb) gives two isostructural two-dimensional MOFs, {[Zn­(3-bpdb)­(suc)]­·(H2O)2} n (1) and {[Zn­(3-bpdb)­(fum)­(H2O)2]} n (2). The use of a straight N,N′-donor ligand, i.e., 1,4-bis­(4-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene (4-bpdb), results in two three-dimensional (3D) MOFs, {[Zn4(4-bpdb)2­(suc)3(OH)2]­·5­(H2O)} n (3) and {[Zn­(4-bpdb)­(fum)]­·(H2O)2} n (4). Here, 3 is a pillared layer structure, whereas 4 has a 5-fold interpenetrated dimondoid network. For both the bent and straight N,N′-donor ligands an imine alike motif is embedded in the structure. When this motif is replaced by a C–C double bond by using the ligand 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethylene (bpee), it produces two MOFs, {[Zn­(bpee)­(suc)]2­·(H2O)3} n (5) and {[Zn2(bpee)2­(fum)2]­·(H2O)} n (6), having a similar structural relation like 3 and 4 respectively, 5 with a pillared layer structure and 6 with a 5-fold interpenetrated diamondoid network. All the compounds have been thoroughly characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), elemental analysis, infrared (IR) spectroscopy, UV–vis spectroscopy, and thermogravimetric analyses. Gas/solvent vapor sorption studies have been carried out for compounds 3–6, which have 3D structures. In the case of 3, an interesting reversible crystalline to crystalline transformation was observed which has been thoroughly studied by PXRD analysis, IR spectroscopy, and UV–vis spectroscopy. Solid state emission spectral analysis for all the complexes was performed at room temperature.

elements.content: This study reports on the structure diversity of six functionalized metal−organic frameworks of Zn­(II), synthesized using one rigid or flexible dicarboxylate along with three different N,N′-donor ligands. Various physicochemical analyses suggest their properties are consistent with the structural outcome.
elements.clean_text: This study reports on the structure diversity of six functionalized metal-organic frameworks of Zn(II), synthesized using one rigid or flexible dicarboxylate along with three different N,N'-donor ligands. Various physicochemical analyses suggest their properties are consistent with the structural outcome.

elements.content: For the past decade, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have remained in the effective domain of interest for chemists, due to their fascinating properties as well as their applications in several areas of modern importance. The structure–property relationship of these MOFs is one of the major criteria for the investigation of such systems for their possible real world applications. In connection to that, it has been found that although some of the physical properties of MOFs have been well interpreted on the basis of their structures, many of those are yet to determined. It has been also observed that careful design with the use of suitable linkers/colinkers along with appropriate metal ions may originate materials with desired structural arrangement which will endorse specific applications of interest as well. In an MOF, structural arrangement of the building unit and the resultant overall framework topology are generally the key factor for the bulk-property of that particular system and that is why it is always important to analyze the topology of the system. Therefore, the logical design of MOFs with the use of well-established strategies of reticular chemistry, i.e., through judicious metal–ligand combination, produces recurrent structural diversity with captivating topologies and tunable properties for the achievement of next generation materials.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

For the past decade, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have remained in the effective domain of interest for chemists, due to their fascinating properties as well as their applications in several areas of modern importance. The structure-property relationship of these MOFs is one of the major criteria for the investigation of such systems for their possible real world applications. In connection to that, it has been found that although some of the physical properties of MOFs have been well interpreted on the basis of their structures, many of those are yet to determined. It has been also observed that careful design with the use of suitable linkers/colinkers along with appropriate metal ions may originate materials with desired structural arrangement which will endorse specific applications of interest as well. In an MOF, structural arrangement of the building unit and the resultant overall framework topology are generally the key factor for the bulk-property of that particular system and that is why it is always important to analyze the topology of the system. Therefore, the logical design of MOFs with the use of well-established strategies of reticular chemistry, i.e., through judicious metal-ligand combination, produces recurrent structural diversity with captivating topologies and tunable properties for the achievement of next generation materials.

elements.content: It is worth mentioning that MOFs with various functional pores always have remained in the limelight for their various applications, and in the synthesis of such MOFs, the use of multi-carboxylic acid donors and pyridyl-containing coligands have been proven to be an efficient strategy. Successful synthesis of the materials incorporating the aforesaid verity of ligands will serve the purpose of design, and also it is important to classify the core architecture or the topologies. The ligands with acyclic multicarboxylate donors provide topologically appealing structures, and the employment of pyridyl colinkers can enhance this diversity in a multiplicative manner. In addition, changing the position of the donor atom and/or introduction of double bonds, and/or atom replacement in a ligand motif may enhance functionality as this effectively changes the coordination pattern and hence the nature of bulk or surface property of the system. On the other hand, the type of metal ion is also an active factor to create the overall structure, affecting functionality as well. It has been observed that Zn­(II) containing MOFs are found with enormous possibility of various applications like host–guest chemistry, luminescent materials, OLED or NLO materials, heterogeneous catalysis and so forth.

In addition, changing the position of the donor atom and/or introduction of double bonds, and/or atom replacement in a ligand motif may enhance functionality as this effectively changes the coordination pattern and hence the nature of bulk or surface property of the system. On the other hand, the type of metal ion is also an active factor to create the overall structure, affecting functionality as well. It has been observed that Zn(II) containing MOFs are found with enormous possibility of various applications like host-guest chemistry, luminescent materials, OLED or NLO materials, heterogeneous catalysis and so forth.

elements.content: With an attempt for a detailed investigation of the above-mentioned understanding, Zn­(II) has been chosen as the metal center in this present work, and we have synthesized six MOFs () with three different N,N′ donor ligands and a flexible and rigid dicarboxylate, namely, succinate and fumarate respectively (). The use of a bent coordinating 1,4-bis­(3-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene (3-bpdb) along with succinate (suc) and fumarate (fum) results in the formation of two isostructural two-dimensional (2D) MOFs, {[Zn­(3-bpdb)­(suc)]­·(H2O)2} n (1) and {[Zn­(3-bpdb)­(fum)­(H2O)2]} n (2). The use of straight chain 1,4-bis­(4-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene (4-bpdb), along with the same dicarboxylates used in previous case, results the formation of three-dimensional (3D) MOFs {[Zn4(4-bpdb)4­(suc)3­(OH)2]­·5­(H2O)} n (3) and {[Zn­(4-bpdb)­(fum)]­·(H2O)2} n (4). Here 3 shows a pillared layer structure, and 4 is a 5-fold interpenetrated dimondoid network. Now moving to the use of a shorter length ligand straight linker, 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethylene (bpee), along with suc and fum produced two MOFs, {[Zn­(bpee)­(suc)]2­·(H2O)3} n (5) and {[Zn2(bpee)2­(fum)2]­·(H2O)} n (6), where a similar structural difference like 3 and 4 has been found. The 5 shows a pillar-layer structure and fum containing 6 produced a 5-fold interpenetrated diamondoid network. All these observations are based upon the characterization of the above compounds using single crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), elemental analysis, infrared (IR) spectroscopy, UV–vis spectroscopy, thermogravimetric (TG) analyses. The gas/solvent vapor sorption study has been performed for all four 3D compounds (3–6). In the case of 3 an interesting reversible crystalline to crystalline transformation was observed, which has been thoroughly investigated by PXRD analysis, IR spectroscopy, and UV–vis spectroscopy. Photoluminescence of all the compounds along with their constituent ligands has also been studied.

elements.content: Highly pure Zn­(NO3)2­·6H2O, 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethylene (bpee), pyridene-4-aldehyde, and pyridene-3-aldehyde were purchased from the Sigma-Aldrich Chemical Co. All other reagents and solvents were purchased from commercial sources and were used without further purification. 1,4-Bis­(3-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene (3-bpdb) and 1,4-bis­(4-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene (4-bpdb) were synthesized by a typical condensation reaction between pyridene-4-aldehyde or pyridene-3-aldehyde and hydrazine hydrate following the reported procedure. Na2-suc or Na2-fum were synthesized by the slow addition of solid NaHCO3 to the corresponding acid (H2-suc and H2-fum respectively) in water in a 2:1 ratio and was allowed to evaporate until dryness.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

Highly pure Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O, 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene (bpee), pyridene-4-aldehyde, and pyridene-3-aldehyde were purchased from the Sigma-Aldrich Chemical Co. All other reagents and solvents were purchased from commercial sources and were used without further purification. 1,4-Bis(3-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene (3-bpdb) and 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)-2,3-diaza-1,3-butadiene (4-bpdb) were synthesized by a typical condensation reaction between pyridene-4-aldehyde or pyridene-3-aldehyde and hydrazine hydrate following the reported procedure. Na2-suc or Na2-fum were synthesized by the slow addition of solid NaHCO3 to the corresponding acid (H2-suc and H2-fum respectively) in water in a 2:1 ratio and was allowed to evaporate until dryness.

elements.content: Elemental analyses (carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen) were performed using a Heraeus CHNS elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra (4000–400 cm–1) were taken on KBr pellet, using Perkin–Elmer Spectrum BX-II IR spectrometer. TGA was carried out on a METTLER TOLEDO TGA 850 thermal analyzer under nitrogen atmosphere (flow rate: 30 cm3 min–1) at the temperature range 30–600 °C with a heating rate of 2 °C/min. PXRD patterns in different states of the samples were recorded on a Bruker D8 Discover instrument using Cu–Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å), operating at 40 kV and 40 mA. Absorption spectra of the solid samples were collected in Perkin–Elmer Lamda-35 instrument with integrating sphere arrangement. Fluorescence measurements were done using Horiba FluoroMax 4.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Measurements

Elemental analyses (carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen) were performed using a Heraeus CHNS elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra (4000-400 cm-1) were taken on KBr pellet, using Perkin-Elmer Spectrum BX-II IR spectrometer. TGA was carried out on a METTLER TOLEDO TGA 850 thermal analyzer under nitrogen atmosphere (flow rate: 30 cm3 min-1) at the temperature range 30-600 °C with a heating rate of 2 °C/min. PXRD patterns in different states of the samples were recorded on a Bruker D8 Discover instrument using Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å), operating at 40 kV and 40 mA. Absorption spectra of the solid samples were collected in Perkin-Elmer Lamda-35 instrument with integrating sphere arrangement. Fluorescence measurements were done using Horiba FluoroMax 4.

elements.content: An aqueous solution (4 mL) of disodium salt of succinic acid (Na2-suc) (0.25 mmol, 41 mg) was mixed slowly with a methanolic solution (4 mL) of 3-bpdb (0.25 mmol, 53 mg) and stirred for 30 min to prepare the mix-ligand solution. Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.25 mmol, 75 mg) was dissolved in 4 mL of water, and then in a long crystal tube 4 mL of Zn­(II) solution was slowly and cautiously layered with the 8 mL of the aforesaid mixed-ligand solution, separated by 2 mL of a 1:1 water–methanol buffer. Yellow needle-shaped single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis were obtained from the junction of the layer after 1 week. The crystals were separated and washed with copious amounts of cold 1:1 (v/v) water and methanol, and dried under air (yield = 71% based on Zn). Anal. Cal. for C16H18N4O6Zn (427.73), 1: C, 44.93; H, 4.24; N, 13.10. Found: C, 44.81; H, 4.42; N, 13.29. IR spectra (KBr pellet, 4000–400 cm–1): 3138 (m), 1632 (s), 1599 (s), 1551 (m), 1468 (s), 1430 (s), 1397 (m), 1313 (s), 1238 (s), 1190 (s), 1162 (m), 1126 (s), 1051 (s), 1027 (m), 974 (m), 946 (m), 874 (m), 812 (m), 701 (m), 661 (m), 641 (m), 407 (s).

Cal. for C32H26N4O9Zn2 (741.35), 6: C, 51.84; H, 3.53; N, 7.56. Found: C, 51.63; H, 3.68; N, 7.37. elements.content: The bulk compounds of 1–6 have been synthesized in powder form by the direct mixing of the corresponding solution of ligands and metal salt in water at an equal molar ratio. For all the compounds a precipitate appeared within 10 min of mixing, and the solution was then stirred further for 3 h, except for 3. For compound 3 the stirring was continued for overnight. The compounds were separated by filtration, and it was washed with a small amount of 1:1 (v/v) methanol/water and dried in air. Compounds purity was verified by PXRD, which gave good correspondence between simulated and bulk-phase PXRD. The purity of the bulk sample was further confirmed by the results of elemental analysis and IR spectra as well, which is also found in accordance with the data obtained for the single crystals.

elements.content: The single crystals of compounds 1–6 were mounted on thin glass fibers with commercially available super glue. Single crystal X-ray data collection of all of these six crystals was done at room temperature using Bruker APEX II diffractometer, equipped with a normal focus, sealed tube X-ray source with graphite monochromated Mo–Kα radiation (λ= 0.71073 Å). The data were integrated using the SAINT program, and the absorption corrections were made with SADABS. All six structures were solved by SHELXS 2014 using the Patterson method and followed by successive Fourier and difference Fourier synthesis. Full matrix least-squares refinements were performed on F2 using SHELXL-2014 with anisotropic displacement parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms. Potential solvent accessible area or void space was calculated using PLATON multipurpose crystallographic software. All the hydrogen atoms were fixed geometrically by HFIX command and placed in ideal positions in case of all structures. Calculations were carried out using SHELXL 2014, SHELXS 2014, PLATON v1.15, ORTEP-3v2, WinGX system Ver-1.80, and TOPOS. Data collection and structure refinement parameters along with crystallographic data for 1–6 are given in .
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal Structure Analysis

The single crystals of compounds 1-6 were mounted on thin glass fibers with commercially available super glue. Single crystal X-ray data collection of all of these six crystals was done at room temperature using Bruker APEX II diffractometer, equipped with a normal focus, sealed tube X-ray source with graphite monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ= 0.71073 Å). The data were integrated using the SAINT program, and the absorption corrections were made with SADABS. All six structures were solved by SHELXS 2014 using the Patterson method and followed by successive Fourier and difference Fourier synthesis. Full matrix least-squares refinements were performed on F2 using SHELXL-2014 with anisotropic displacement parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms. Potential solvent accessible area or void space was calculated using PLATON multipurpose crystallographic software. All the hydrogen atoms were fixed geometrically by HFIX command and placed in ideal positions in case of all structures. Calculations were carried out using SHELXL 2014, SHELXS 2014, PLATON v1.15, ORTEP-3v2, WinGX system Ver-1.80, and TOPOS. Data collection and structure refinement parameters along with crystallographic data for 1-6 are given in .

Ambient pressure volumetric N2 gas adsorption studies were carried out at 77 K with the desolvated samples of 3 (3′), 4, 5, and 6, maintained by a liquid-nitrogen bath, in the relative pressures ranging from 0 to 1 using a Quantachrome Autosorb-iQ adsorption instrument. CO2 sorption measurements were also performed at 195 K (dry ice-acetone cold bath) with same pressure range and on same instrument. High purity gases were used for the adsorption measurements (nitrogen, 99.999%; carbon dioxide, 99.95%). For water vapor sorption measurement, the experiment was performed at 298 K in the pressure range 0–0.9 with the same instrument. The extent of adsorption was determined by monitoring the change in pressure at the equilibrium state of the sample tube containing adsorbates. All operations were computer-controlled and automatic.
elements.clean_text:
Sorption Measurements

Ambient pressure volumetric N2 gas adsorption studies were carried out at 77 K with the desolvated samples of 3 (3'), 4, 5, and 6, maintained by a liquid-nitrogen bath, in the relative pressures ranging from 0 to 1 using a Quantachrome Autosorb-iQ adsorption instrument. CO2 sorption measurements were also performed at 195 K (dry ice-acetone cold bath) with same pressure range and on same instrument. High purity gases were used for the adsorption measurements (nitrogen, 99.999%; carbon dioxide, 99.95%). For water vapor sorption measurement, the experiment was performed at 298 K in the pressure range 0-0.9 with the same instrument. The extent of adsorption was determined by monitoring the change in pressure at the equilibrium state of the sample tube containing adsorbates. All operations were computer-controlled and automatic.

elements.content: At room temperature Zn­(II) along with salt of two dicarboxylic acids and three different N,N′-donor linkers, 3-bpdb (1 and 2), 4-bpdb (3 and 4), and bpee (5 and 6) in methanol/water medium were used for synthesis of all the compounds 1–6 employing a slow diffusion technique ().
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

At room temperature Zn(II) along with salt of two dicarboxylic acids and three different N,N'-donor linkers, 3-bpdb (1 and 2), 4-bpdb (3 and 4), and bpee (5 and 6) in methanol/water medium were used for synthesis of all the compounds 1-6 employing a slow diffusion technique ().

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis revealed that compounds 1 and 2 are isostructural having monoclinic P21 /n space group with the only difference in the nature of the dicarboxylate linkers (succinate in 1 and fumarate in 2). Both the compounds show the formation of a 2D structure of Zn (II) ions linked by a 3-bpdb linker and bridging succinate in the case of 1 and fumarate in the case of 2. Here, in both cases a Zn­(II) center is located in a special position (1, 0, 1), and the asymmetric unit contains half of Zn­(II) along with half 3-bpdb linker, half dicarboxylate ligand, and one coordinated water molecule. Here, each hexacoordinated Zn­(II) center with ZnN2O4 binding set displays a distorted octahedral geometry created by two carboxylate O atoms (O1 and O1 a ) from two different dicarboxylate (suc in 1 and fum in 2), two symmetry generated coordinated water molecules (O1W and O1W a ), and two 3-pyridyl nitrogen atoms (N1 and N1 a ) from two 3-bpdb linkers (a for 1 and b for 2).

Structural Description of {[Zn(3-bpdb)(suc)(H2O)2]} n  (1) and {[Zn(3-bpdb)(fum)(H2O)2]} n  (2)

Here, in both cases a Zn(II) center is located in a special position (1, 0, 1), and the asymmetric unit contains half of Zn(II) along with half 3-bpdb linker, half dicarboxylate ligand, and one coordinated water molecule. Here, each hexacoordinated Zn(II) center with ZnN2O4 binding set displays a distorted octahedral geometry created by two carboxylate O atoms (O1 and O1 a ) from two different dicarboxylate (suc in 1 and fum in 2), two symmetry generated coordinated water molecules (O1W and O1W a ), and two 3-pyridyl nitrogen atoms (N1 and N1 a ) from two 3-bpdb linkers (a for 1 and b for 2).

elements.content: In 1 and 2, Zn–O bond lengths vary from 2.0522(14)–2.0985(15) Å and 2.056(3)–2.095(3) Å, respectively, and the corresponding Zn–N bond lengths are 2.2093(18) (Table S1) and 2.200(4) (Table S2) for 1 and 2, respectively. The selected bond lengths and bond angles are reported in Table S1 for 1 and Table S2 for 2. Here, each dicarboxylate ligand binds in a bridging monodentate fashion in between two Zn­(II) centers resulting in the formation of a 1D metal carboxylate chain (Figure S2a for 1 and Figure S2b for 2). The 1D metal-carboxylate chains are joined by the 3-bpdb linkers to form a 2D arrangement in the crystallographic ab plane (a for 1 and b for 2).

elements.content: Taking a straight chain linker 4-bpdb instead of a bent angular linker 3-bpdb, there is a change in the binding mode as well as an enhancement of the flexibility of the N,N′-donor linker, which exerts a marked effect on the overall structure of the MOFs. This features, probably, affect the rising of dimensionality for both the structures obtained with 4-bpdb. Single crystal X-ray structure determination of compound 3 reveals that it is a 3D network made up of Zn­(II), suc dianion, and 4-bpdb spacer, and the crystal belongs to the triclinic P1̅ space group. In the asymmetric unit, there are two crystallographic independent Zn­(II) ions (Zn1 and Zn2), one 4-bpdb linker, one and half of suc, and a bridging OH group. Two Zn­(II) centers are in two different geometrical arrangements. The hexacoordinated Zn1 centers are in a distorted octahedral geometry with a ZnO5N1 binding set, and the coordination is provided by one 4-pyridyl nitrogen (N1) of 4-bpdb spacer, three carboxylate oxygen (O3, O4 b and O6) atoms from three different suc ligands, and two oxygens of bridging hydroxyl group (O1 and O1 c ) (a). Every hydroxyl group further connects one more Zn1 and a tetrahedral Zn2 center. The four-coordinated Zn2 is with a ZnO3N1 binding set which is satisfied by the hydroxyl group, two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2 and O5 b ) from two bridging suc ligands, and one 4-pyridyl nitrogen (N4 a ) atom of 4-bpdb (a). The details of Zn–O and Zn–N bond lengths are depicted in Table S5. Among them, the Zn1–O bond length is in the range of 2.048(5)–2.218(6) Å and the Zn1–N bond lengths are 2.136(6) Å. However, the Zn2–O bond lengths lies in the range of 1.912(5)–1.980(5) Å, and Zn2–N the bond lengths are 2.031(6) Å. Thus, two sets of Zn2 (Zn1 and Zn2), connected with the help of the hydroxyl group, form the secondary building unit (Figure S4) having the unit formula Zn4N4O12. Two such units are connected by bridging suc and extend the structure along crystallographic a axis. A set of two connected suc farther, bonded to two Zn1 atoms of two different SBUs and extend the structure to a Zn-suc sheet in the ab direction (b). Such sheets are farther linked by 4-bpdb linkers along the c axis to form the ultimate 3D structure (c). Beyond that, the structure is further stabilized by the intermolecular π–π interaction (Figure S5), and details about that are presented in Table S6. From the topological analysis by TOPOS, it is revealed that this 3D structure can be represented as a binodal 5,7-c net (d) with the Schläfli symbol {34.44.52}­{35.45.55.66}. The distance of two Zn1 through the two-connected suc is 8.99 Å, and Zn1–Zn2 through 4-bpdb is 15.457 Å. These large distances eventually create quadrilateral pores along the a direction, which are occupied by lattice water molecules (c). On removal of the free water molecules, the solvent-accessible void space of 3 calculated by PLATON is 286 Å3, which is about 23.1% of the total unit cell volume.

Every hydroxyl group further connects one more Zn1 and a tetrahedral Zn2 center. The four-coordinated Zn2 is with a ZnO3N1 binding set which is satisfied by the hydroxyl group, two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2 and O5 b ) from two bridging suc ligands, and one 4-pyridyl nitrogen (N4 a ) atom of 4-bpdb (a). Thus, two sets of Zn2 (Zn1 and Zn2), connected with the help of the hydroxyl group, form the secondary building unit (Figure S4) having the unit formula Zn4N4O12. elements.content: Now, on introduction of a double bond in the dicarboxylate by use of more rigid fum instead flexible suc along with 4-bpdb and Zn­(II) yielded yellow crystal of compound 4 having a 5-fold interpenetrated diamond-type framework, which crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c. Structural analysis illustrates that the asymmetric unit of 4 consists of one and half of Zn­(II), fum, 4-bpdb ligands, and two one-half of guest water molecules (a). Here, each Zn­(II) center exhibits a four coordinated distorted tetrahedral geometry with an N2O2 donor set bonded to two oxygen atoms (O1, O1 a ) from two different fum ligands by monodentate bridging fashion and two nitrogen atoms (N1, N1 a ) from two different 4-bpdb linkers (a). Here all the Zn–O and Zn–N bonds are 1.946(3) Å and 2.041(3) respectively. All the bond distances and bond angles around Zn­(II) centers are presented in Table S7.

elements.content: Each fum and 4-bpdb bridges two Zn­(II) centers, and the arrangement finally leads to large adamantane-like cages (b). In such an adamantane cage, Zn···Zn distances through 4-bpdb and fum are ∼15.4 and ∼8.8 Å, respectively. These adamantoid cages are interconnected and extended to form a 3D diamondoid network with large hexagonal channels of a dimension about 18.9 × 14.4 Å2 (c). Topologically the framework can be presented as a 4-connected uninodal net with the Schläfli symbol {66} (f). Every diamondoid 3D network is interpenetrated with another four equivalent diamondoid networks to form a Class Ia 5-fold interpenetrated dimondoid network (e,f). Notably, the channels dimension is sufficiently decreased, and the overall 1D rectangular channels of dimension 9.6 × 7.3 Å2 along the b axis occur and guest water molecules reside in these channels (d). By PLATON the solvent-accessible void space of 4 was calculated and found as 27.5% of the total crystal volume.

elements.content: Compound 5 crystallizes in the orthorhombic Fdd2 space group, and the single-crystal X-ray structure analysis reveals the formation of a 3D network structure with Zn­(II) metal ions connected by suc dianion and bpee linkers. The asymmetric unit of 5 contains one Zn­(II) atom, one bridging bpee ligand, one succinate and one and half lattice water molecules. As shown in a, each Zn­(II) center with O2N2 binding set is coordinated with two 4-pyridyl nitrogen atoms (N1 and N2 b ) from two different linear bpee linkers and two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1 and O3 a ) from two different bridging succinate displaying a distorted tetrahedral geometry. The Zn–O bond lengths lie in the range of 1.929(3)–1.947(3) Å, whereas Zn–N bond lengths are 2.029(3)–2.066(2) Å (Table S8). Other bond lengths and angles of Zn­(II) coordination spheres are listed in Table S8. Here, each suc dianion binds two Zn­(II) centers in a bridging monodentate fashion to yield a undulating [Zn­(suc)] n chain (Figure S7a), which is further cross-linked by bpee coligands along two different directions (b) to develop a 3D porous framework with the 1D channel along the crystallographic b-axis, which is occupied by lattice guest water molecules (c). As calculated by PLATON, without these lattice water molecules, the solvent-accessible void space of 5 is found as 7.8% of the total crystal volume. The structure is further stabilized by π–π weak interaction (Figure S7b). Details are provided in Table S9. The TOPOS analysis reveals that the structure can be represented as a 4-connected uninodal net (d) with Schläfli symbol for net {42.84}.

elements.content: Compound 6 crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group, and the single crystal X-ray structure determination reveals a 3D 5-fold interpenetrating diamondoid network made up of Zn­(II), fum dianion, and bpee spacer. The asymmetric unit contains two crystallographically independent Zn­(II) ions (Zn1 and Zn2), one complete fum ligand, halves of two fum ligands with other environment, one complete bpee linker, halves of two other bpee linkers and one guest water molecule (a). The pentacoordinated Zn1 center is in a distorted square pyramidal geometry with 0.32 Addison parameter (tau) value and O3N2 binding set satisfied by four carboxylate oxygen (O3, O7 and O8) atoms from two bridging fum ligands and two 4-pyridyl nitrogen (N2 and N3) atoms from two different bpee spacers (a). The hexacoordinated Zn2 shows a distorted octahedral geometry with a O4N2 binding set, and the coordination is provided by four carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O5, and O6) from two bridging fum ligands and two 4-pyridyl nitrogen (N1 and N4 a ) atoms from two different bpee spacers (a). The Zn–O and Zn–N bond lengths and related angles for Zn1 and Zn2 centers are slightly different (Table S10). Among them, the Zn1–O and Zn1–N bond lengths are in the range of 1.9524(17)–2.6041(19) Å and 2.0466(18)–2.0609(18) Å, respectively. However, the Zn2–O bond lengths lies 2.116(2)–2.5352(19) Å, and Zn2–N the bond lengths are 2.0468(18) and 2.0886(19) Å. Other bond lengths and angles within the coordination spheres are listed in Table S10. Both the Zn­(II) ions act as 4-connected nodes which are connected with each other by the fum and bpee linkers to generate a large adamantane-like cages (b and S8a-b). Topological analysis by TOPOS reveals that the structure can be represented as a 4-connected dia net topology (c,e) with the Schläfli point symbol {66}. Because of the crystallographic difference between the fum dianion ligands, the Zn···Zn distances through fum are 8.747, 8.902, and 9.148 Å, whereas Zn···Zn distances through the three crystallographically different bpee ligands are 13.377, 13.437, and 13.439 Å. These adamantoid cages are interlinked and extended to form a 3D diamondoid network with large hexagonal channels of about 16.7 × 19.4 Å2 (d,e), which facilitate further nucleation in the void spaces and allow the formation of equivalent diamondoid net in those regions to generate a Class Ia 5-fold interpenetrated dimondoid network (d,e). Calculation by PLATON suggests that this system contains a 5.5% solvent accessible void of total crystallographic volume without the lattice water molecules.

elements.content: From the above discussion of all the structures, it is evident that the ligands have a marked influence on the overall structure of the compounds. In the case of 1 and 2, the ultimate structure is influenced by the bent nature of the 3-bpdb ligand, resulting in the same structure thumping the effect rigid or flexible colinkers. On moving to a straight coordinating N,N′ donor ligand, the enhancement in flexibility may lead to the formation of the higher dimensional structures. Structural similarity in 3/5 and 4/6 pairs suggests here the overall structures are less directed by the N,N′ donor ligand in comparison to that of 1 and 2. As described earlier in last two pairs, both succinate containing 3 and 5 gives pillared layer 3D structures, whereas fumarate containing 4 and 6 forms a Class Ia 5-fold interpenetrated structure. The rigidity of the fumarate is possibly responsible for the formation of rigid large hexagonal channels which finally turns into the interpenetrated structures.

elements.content: To study the framework stability of the compounds 1–6, thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) studies are carried out. For both the studies a crystalline powder sample is used, and TGA has been carried out in the range of 25–650 °C (Figure S9). Single crystal analysis has shown that isostructural compounds 1 and 2 have no solvent molecule, and TGA is consistent with this; there is no significant weight loss up to ∼200 °C for both of them, and then a steady decrease of weight loss was observed. Eventually, compound 3 shows a gradual weight loss with a step of 7.66% (40–80 °C), which corresponds to the escape of guest water molecules and the weight loss is equivalent to ∼5 (4.88) water molecules. The desolvated framework is stable up to 150 °C, and after that it steadily disintegrates to unrecognized product. The TGA curve (Figure S9) of compound 4 shows there is no significant weight loss up to 90 °C, and then it starts a gradual weight loss with a step of 8.12% up to 190 °C, corresponding to ∼2 water molecules. This dehydrated framework is stable up to 270 °C. Afterward it continuously dissociates to an unidentified product. TGA of 5 depicts that guest water molecules started to escape just after 40 °C and continuous up to 137 °C. A certain change in slope at ∼137 °C indicates that guest molecules are completely removed from the system with a ∼7% weight loss, which is equivalent to ∼3 water molecules. Afterward with almost the same rate (but not equal) it dissociates to unrecognized products. From TGA it has been revealed that compound 6 shows a sharp weight loss with a step of 2.48% (60–90 °C), corresponding to the escape of one guest water molecule from the compound. This dehydrated framework is stable up to 370 °C with no significant weight loss. This is followed by a sharp weight loss, caused by an unrecognized product probably due to the decomposition of the frameworks.

Thermogravimetric Analysis (TG) and Powder X-ray Diffraction (PXRD) Study

To study the framework stability of the compounds 1-6, thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) studies are carried out. For both the studies a crystalline powder sample is used, and TGA has been carried out in the range of 25-650 °C (Figure S9). Single crystal analysis has shown that isostructural compounds 1 and 2 have no solvent molecule, and TGA is consistent with this; there is no significant weight loss up to ~200 °C for both of them, and then a steady decrease of weight loss was observed. Eventually, compound 3 shows a gradual weight loss with a step of 7.66% (40-80 °C), which corresponds to the escape of guest water molecules and the weight loss is equivalent to ~5 (4.88) water molecules. The desolvated framework is stable up to 150 °C, and after that it steadily disintegrates to unrecognized product. The TGA curve (Figure S9) of compound 4 shows there is no significant weight loss up to 90 °C, and then it starts a gradual weight loss with a step of 8.12% up to 190 °C, corresponding to ~2 water molecules. This dehydrated framework is stable up to 270 °C. Afterward it continuously dissociates to an unidentified product. TGA of 5 depicts that guest water molecules started to escape just after 40 °C and continuous up to 137 °C. A certain change in slope at ~137 °C indicates that guest molecules are completely removed from the system with a ~7% weight loss, which is equivalent to ~3 water molecules. Afterward with almost the same rate (but not equal) it dissociates to unrecognized products. From TGA it has been revealed that compound 6 shows a sharp weight loss with a step of 2.48% (60-90 °C), corresponding to the escape of one guest water molecule from the compound. This dehydrated framework is stable up to 370 °C with no significant weight loss. This is followed by a sharp weight loss, caused by an unrecognized product probably due to the decomposition of the frameworks.

elements.content: The PXRD pattern of the desolvated phase of 3 (3′) displays shifting of a few peak positions along with the appearance of some new peaks in comparison to the as-synthesized pattern of 3 (), signifying, rather than disintegration, structural transformation after removal of lattice water molecules has taken place. Indexing of the PXRD data of 3′ (Figure S10) using the TREOR program implies a structural contraction along the c axis by 23.48% (Table S11) associated with a reduction of 21.11% in volume after the removal of the solvent molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Study of Crystalline to Crystalline Transformation in 3 

The PXRD pattern of the desolvated phase of 3 (3') displays shifting of a few peak positions along with the appearance of some new peaks in comparison to the as-synthesized pattern of 3 (), signifying, rather than disintegration, structural transformation after removal of lattice water molecules has taken place. Indexing of the PXRD data of 3' (Figure S10) using the TREOR program implies a structural contraction along the c axis by 23.48% (Table S11) associated with a reduction of 21.11% in volume after the removal of the solvent molecules.

elements.content: On immersion of 3′ in water as well as in a water–methanol mixture, there is a formation of compound 3″, whose PXRD pattern is similar to that of the major peak found for the simulated pattern of 3 (). That is on rehydration of 3′ it again was restored to its original phase. There is an additional peak at 2θ = 7.2° for both the water as well as water–methanol mixture immersed product, which is possibly due to unorganized crystal packing.

elements.content: This transformation is also monitored using IR and UV–vis spectroscopy. In IR spectroscopy broadening of peaks along with shifting of some peaks has been observed (Figure S11), which suggests a change, in the coordination environment around the metal center. In UV–vis spectroscopy, a ∼20 nm shift in the maxima was observed for 3′ with respect to 3 of the peak at ∼370 nm. The maximum at ∼330 nm is totally absent in 3′ (Figure S12). Again on rehydration the maxima positions are restored as that of as-synthesized (Figure S12). Thus, the mentioned transformation is reversible with respect to treatment with the water and water–methanol mixture.

elements.content: Among the structures reported here, only 3 and 6 consist of two crystallographically independent metal (ZnII) centers, whereas the others have only one independent metal center in their unit cell. Upon dehydration of 3 there may be a possibility of reorganization in the structure through the flexible succinate dianion linkage. This conversion may lead to form an uniform Zn­(II) center in the transformed phase (3′), which is somehow supported by the contraction of cell volume in the activated form of compound 3 (3′). But compound 6 being a dense interpenetrated structure consisting of rigid fumarate is not prone to show such dynamicity, which has been observed in 3.

But compound 6 being a dense interpenetrated structure consisting of rigid fumarate is not prone to show such dynamicity, which has been observed in 3.

elements.content: As revealed from the single crystal XRD structural analysis, 3, 4, 5, and 6 have water filled cavities, and the pore dimensions are comparable to the kinetic diameter of the gases and solvent vapors of recent interest. Except 3, all other framework stability is supported by TGA and PXRD measurements. As stated earlier, 3 undergoes a structural transformation during the dehydration, although the transformed framework, 3′, is quite stable up to a certain high temperature. With all of the dehydrated frameworks a sorption study has been performed using different gases (N2 at 77 K and CO2 at 195 K) and vapors (H2O at 298 K). All of these samples show a negligible amount of N2 uptake with a type-II surface adsorption (a).
elements.clean_text:
Adsorption Properties

As revealed from the single crystal XRD structural analysis, 3, 4, 5, and 6 have water filled cavities, and the pore dimensions are comparable to the kinetic diameter of the gases and solvent vapors of recent interest. Except 3, all other framework stability is supported by TGA and PXRD measurements. As stated earlier, 3 undergoes a structural transformation during the dehydration, although the transformed framework, 3', is quite stable up to a certain high temperature. With all of the dehydrated frameworks a sorption study has been performed using different gases (N2 at 77 K and CO2 at 195 K) and vapors (H2O at 298 K). All of these samples show a negligible amount of N2 uptake with a type-II surface adsorption (a).

elements.content: A similar phenomenon is observed for the CO2 also, which also ends up with a very low uptake (b). Despite a large pore, low N2 uptake may be due to low thermal energy of N2 at 77 K which may not overcome the high diffusion barrier causing exclusion, whereas for CO2 the blocking of the windows of unidirectional pore channels to the incoming larger sized CO2 gas molecules may be the reason for such low uptake. Besides, although 3 has a very large pore, a change of structure during the dehydration process by the pore volume is mostly compromised resulting in a low adsorption.

elements.content: However, the water adsorption shows enhancement of the amount of adsorption accompanied by some interesting phenomenon. The H2O adsorption profile for 3′ exhibits a gate opening phenomenon; no uptake (∼5 mL g–1) occurs at low pressure and then at P/P 0 ≈ 0.422, a sharp rise takes place up to P/P 0 ≈ 0.599, associated with an uptake of 207 mL g–1, and the final uptake amount reaches 235.6 mL g–1 (c). The final uptake amount is equivalent to a total of 12 water molecules; i.e., the converted structure can uptake more water molecules than the number present in its mother compound. For 4, a type II adsorption is observed with a final uptake of ∼69.3 mL g–1. There is a certain interesting scenario with 5; it uptakes water up to P/P 0 ≈ 0.17 with a continuous rate of ∼61 mL g–1, equivalent to 2.1 water molecules, and then there is a change in the rate of adsorption, which ends at P/P 0 ≈ 0.35, of ∼85 mL g–1, equivalent to a total of three water molecules (c). Again a change of rate is observed and the final amount reaches ∼150.3 mL g–1 at P/P 0 ≈ 0.90, which is equivalent to ∼5 (5.2) molecules of water. No significant adsorption is observed for 6; the final amount is ∼38.6 mL g−1(c).

elements.content: This is clearly visible that all these metal–organic frameworks with a succinate linker have a greater affinity toward water relative to the coordination polymer containing a fumarate linker with identical coligand. Although a double bond containing fumarate should have a greater tendency to adsorb polar water molecule, a lower adsorption is observed. This may be related to the fact that all the fumarate containing systems are interpenetrated in nature, which may block the pore window and hence such lower adsorption is observed.

elements.content: Optical properties of MOFs with d10 metal centers and recent successful use of them in various applications have brought them one more time under the spotlight of interest of researchers. Solid state photoluminescence study of the d10 complexes 1–6 and free respective ligands were performed at room temperature (). The ligand 3-bpdb and corresponding complexes 1 and 2 show emission maxima at 398 nm (λex = 255 nm), 405 nm (λex = 265 nm), and 408 nm (λex = 265 nm) respectively (a). Similar emission spectra is found for the 4-bpdb and its complexes 3 and 4. Complexes 3 and 4 exhibit emission maxima at 396 nm (λex = 255 nm) and 407 nm (λex = 265 nm) respectively and the ligand 4-bpdb at 394 nm (λex = 250 nm) (b). For the rest, ligand bpee shows emission spectra at 396 nm (λex = 260 nm) where its complexes 5 and 6 show emission maxima at 401 nm (λex = 260 nm) and 396 nm (λex = 250 nm) respectively (c).
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Study

Optical properties of MOFs with d10 metal centers and recent successful use of them in various applications have brought them one more time under the spotlight of interest of researchers. Solid state photoluminescence study of the d10 complexes 1-6 and free respective ligands were performed at room temperature (). The ligand 3-bpdb and corresponding complexes 1 and 2 show emission maxima at 398 nm (λex = 255 nm), 405 nm (λex = 265 nm), and 408 nm (λex = 265 nm) respectively (a). Similar emission spectra is found for the 4-bpdb and its complexes 3 and 4. Complexes 3 and 4 exhibit emission maxima at 396 nm (λex = 255 nm) and 407 nm (λex = 265 nm) respectively and the ligand 4-bpdb at 394 nm (λex = 250 nm) (b). For the rest, ligand bpee shows emission spectra at 396 nm (λex = 260 nm) where its complexes 5 and 6 show emission maxima at 401 nm (λex = 260 nm) and 396 nm (λex = 250 nm) respectively (c).

elements.content: (a–c) Emission spectra for complexes 1–6 with constituent free N,N′-donor linker.
elements.clean_text: 11  (a-c) Emission spectra for complexes 1-6 with constituent free N,N'-donor linker.

elements.content: It is clear from the emission spectrum that the three ligands and their complexes 1–6 exhibit similar types of spectra which are slightly red-shifted compared to the ligand. The emission spectrum of free ligands with aromatic architecture may be originated from the π*–n or π*−π transition. Since the d10 metal ions are difficult to be reduced or oxidized there is less possibility for the metal-associated MLCT/LMCT charge transfer to occur. Thus, the emission property of these compounds may be allocated primarily to the intraligand charge transition (ILCT) and ligand-to-ligand charge transfer (LLCT).
elements.clean_text: It is clear from the emission spectrum that the three ligands and their complexes 1-6 exhibit similar types of spectra which are slightly red-shifted compared to the ligand. The emission spectrum of free ligands with aromatic architecture may be originated from the π*-n or π*-π transition. Since the d10 metal ions are difficult to be reduced or oxidized there is less possibility for the metal-associated MLCT/LMCT charge transfer to occur. Thus, the emission property of these compounds may be allocated primarily to the intraligand charge transition (ILCT) and ligand-to-ligand charge transfer (LLCT).

elements.content: Here syntheses of six Zn­(II) MOFs constructed by succinate and fumarate along with three different N,N′ donor coligands are reported, among them one is bent coordinating and other two are straight coordinating. The ligand differs by chain length and constituent atoms as well. The structural diversity was discussed, and different physicochemical analysis was performed on them for proper characterization. It is also found that one of the compounds shows reversible structural transformation on dehydration and rehydration, which was also thoroughly investigated by different techniques. In addition, results from gas and solvent vapor sorption experiments are found to be quite interesting and consistent with the structural features. From the study it is interesting to note that, despite the use of both flexible and rigid dicarboxylate linkers along with same bent coordinating ligand, 1 and 2 are found to be isostructural and the rigidity or flexibility of a ligand seems to have no effect on the overall structure, although the compounds with straight coordinating linkers have structural similarity as succinate containing pairs 3 and 5, and fumarate containing pairs 4 and 6. The flexible succinate containing compounds are portrayed as a pillared layer structure, whereas fumarate containing compounds show a 5-fold interpenetrated structure. It has been quite ubiquitous that the pillared layer structure is more likely to be formed by a rigid ligand and flexibility in ligand favors interpenetration, but here exactly the opposite trend is observed. Another interesting phenomenon is worth to note: 3 and 5 are made of flexible succinate and linear linker, for 3 the flexibility is transferred to the constructed MOF whereas 5 does not have any structural flexibility as found in 3. Also, 4 with same N,N′-donor linker does not show any structural flexibility like 3. Therefore, it is evident from the present study that a rigid linker can create a flexible structure in a favorable condition and vice versa.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Here syntheses of six Zn(II) MOFs constructed by succinate and fumarate along with three different N,N' donor coligands are reported, among them one is bent coordinating and other two are straight coordinating. The ligand differs by chain length and constituent atoms as well. The structural diversity was discussed, and different physicochemical analysis was performed on them for proper characterization. It is also found that one of the compounds shows reversible structural transformation on dehydration and rehydration, which was also thoroughly investigated by different techniques. In addition, results from gas and solvent vapor sorption experiments are found to be quite interesting and consistent with the structural features. From the study it is interesting to note that, despite the use of both flexible and rigid dicarboxylate linkers along with same bent coordinating ligand, 1 and 2 are found to be isostructural and the rigidity or flexibility of a ligand seems to have no effect on the overall structure, although the compounds with straight coordinating linkers have structural similarity as succinate containing pairs 3 and 5, and fumarate containing pairs 4 and 6. The flexible succinate containing compounds are portrayed as a pillared layer structure, whereas fumarate containing compounds show a 5-fold interpenetrated structure. It has been quite ubiquitous that the pillared layer structure is more likely to be formed by a rigid ligand and flexibility in ligand favors interpenetration, but here exactly the opposite trend is observed. Another interesting phenomenon is worth to note: 3 and 5 are made of flexible succinate and linear linker, for 3 the flexibility is transferred to the constructed MOF whereas 5 does not have any structural flexibility as found in 3. Also, 4 with same N,N'-donor linker does not show any structural flexibility like 3. Therefore, it is evident from the present study that a rigid linker can create a flexible structure in a favorable condition and vice versa.

An aqueous solution (4 mL) of disodium salt of succinic acid (Na2-suc) (0.25 mmol, 41 mg) was mixed slowly with a methanolic solution (4 mL) of 3-bpdb (0.25 mmol, 53 mg) and stirred for 30 min to prepare the mix-ligand solution. Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.25 mmol, 75 mg) was dissolved in 4 mL of water, and then in a long crystal tube 4 mL of Zn­(II) solution was slowly and cautiously layered with the 8 mL of the aforesaid mixed-ligand solution, separated by 2 mL of a 1:1 water–methanol buffer. Yellow needle-shaped single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis were obtained from the junction of the layer after 1 week. The crystals were separated and washed with copious amounts of cold 1:1 (v/v) water and methanol, and dried under air (yield = 71% based on Zn). Anal. Cal. for C16H18N4O6Zn (427.73), 1: C, 44.93; H, 4.24; N, 13.10. Found: C, 44.81; H, 4.42; N, 13.29. IR spectra (KBr pellet, 4000–400 cm–1): 3138 (m), 1632 (s), 1599 (s), 1551 (m), 1468 (s), 1430 (s), 1397 (m), 1313 (s), 1238 (s), 1190 (s), 1162 (m), 1126 (s), 1051 (s), 1027 (m), 974 (m), 946 (m), 874 (m), 812 (m), 701 (m), 661 (m), 641 (m), 407 (s).

Compound 2 was synthesized using the same procedure as that of 1, using a disodium salt of fumaric acid (Na2-fum) (1 mmol, 160 mg) instead of disodium salt of succinic acid (Na2-suc). After 14 days, yellow, needle-shaped crystals were obtained from the middle of the tube and were separated and washed with methanol (yield = 67% based on Zn). Anal. Cal. for C16H16N4O6Zn (625.71), 2: C, 45.14; H, 3.79; N, 13.16. Found: C, 45.02; H, 3.88; N, 13.37. Compound 3 has been synthesized by the same procedure as that of 1 using 4-bpdb (1 mmol, 210 mg) instead of 3-bpdb. Unlike the compounds, here the yellow-colored block crystals were obtained after a longer time. After 7 weeks the crystals were obtained from the middle of the tube and were separated and washed with methanol (yield = 69% based on Zn). Anal. Synthesis of {[Zn­(fum)­(4-bpdb)]­·(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

Compound 4 has been synthesized adopting the same procedure as that of 1, using disodium salt of fumaric acid (Na2-fum) (1 mmol, 160 mg) instead of disodium salt of succinic acid (Na2-suc) and 4-bpdb (1 mmol, 210 mg) instead of 3-bpdb. After 7 days, yellow needle-like crystals were obtained from the middle of the tube and were separated and washed with methanol (yield = 76% based on Zn). Anal. IR spectra (KBr pellet, 4000–400 cm–1): 3435 (b), 1616 (s), 1596 (s), 1428 (s), 1366 (s), 1335 (m), 1228 (m), 1192 (m), 1063 (s), 1029 (s), 957 (m), 823 (s), 799 (s), 693 (s), 517 (s), 427 (s).

Synthesis of {[Zn­(suc)­(bpe)]<sub>2</sub>­·(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>5</bold>)

Compound 5 has been synthesized using the same procedure as that of 1, using 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethylene (bpee) (1 mmol, 182 mg) instead of 3-bpdb. After 14 days, white block crystals were obtained from the middle of the tube and were separated and washed with 1:1 methanol/water (yield = 76% based on Zn). Compound 6 was also synthesized using the same procedure as that of 1, using 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethene (bpee) (1 mmol, 182 mg) instead of 3-bpdb and disodium salt of fumaric acid (Na2-fum) (1 mmol, 160 mg) instead of disodium salt of succinic acid (Na2-suc). After 10 days, white block shaped crystals were obtained from the middle of the tube and were separated and washed with 1:1 methanol/H2O (yield = 65% based on Zn). Anal. cln_elements.content:
Each fum and 4-bpdb bridges two Zn­(II) centers, and the arrangement finally leads to large adamantane-like cages (b). In such an adamantane cage, Zn···Zn distances through 4-bpdb and fum are ∼15.4 and ∼8.8 Å, respectively. These adamantoid cages are interconnected and extended to form a 3D diamondoid network with large hexagonal channels of a dimension about 18.9 × 14.4 Å2 (c). Topologically the framework can be presented as a 4-connected uninodal net with the Schläfli symbol {66} (f). Every diamondoid 3D network is interpenetrated with another four equivalent diamondoid networks to form a Class Ia 5-fold interpenetrated dimondoid network (e,f). Notably, the channels dimension is sufficiently decreased, and the overall 1D rectangular channels of dimension 9.6 × 7.3 Å2 along the b axis occur and guest water molecules reside in these channels (d). By PLATON the solvent-accessible void space of 4 was calculated and found as 27.5% of the total crystal volume.

Thermogravimetric Analysis (TG) and Powder X-ray Diffraction (PXRD) Study

To study the framework stability of the compounds 1–6, thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) studies are carried out. For both the studies a crystalline powder sample is used, and TGA has been carried out in the range of 25–650 °C (Figure S9). Single crystal analysis has shown that isostructural compounds 1 and 2 have no solvent molecule, and TGA is consistent with this; there is no significant weight loss up to ∼200 °C for both of them, and then a steady decrease of weight loss was observed. Eventually, compound 3 shows a gradual weight loss with a step of 7.66% (40–80 °C), which corresponds to the escape of guest water molecules and the weight loss is equivalent to ∼5 (4.88) water molecules. The desolvated framework is stable up to 150 °C, and after that it steadily disintegrates to unrecognized product. The TGA curve (Figure S9) of compound 4 shows there is no significant weight loss up to 90 °C, and then it starts a gradual weight loss with a step of 8.12% up to 190 °C, corresponding to ∼2 water molecules. This dehydrated framework is stable up to 270 °C. Afterward it continuously dissociates to an unidentified product. TGA of 5 depicts that guest water molecules started to escape just after 40 °C and continuous up to 137 °C. A certain change in slope at ∼137 °C indicates that guest molecules are completely removed from the system with a ∼7% weight loss, which is equivalent to ∼3 water molecules. Afterward with almost the same rate (but not equal) it dissociates to unrecognized products. From TGA it has been revealed that compound 6 shows a sharp weight loss with a step of 2.48% (60–90 °C), corresponding to the escape of one guest water molecule from the compound. This dehydrated framework is stable up to 370 °C with no significant weight loss. This is followed by a sharp weight loss, caused by an unrecognized product probably due to the decomposition of the frameworks.

However, the water adsorption shows enhancement of the amount of adsorption accompanied by some interesting phenomenon. The H2O adsorption profile for 3′ exhibits a gate opening phenomenon; no uptake (∼5 mL g–1) occurs at low pressure and then at P/P 0 ≈ 0.422, a sharp rise takes place up to P/P 0 ≈ 0.599, associated with an uptake of 207 mL g–1, and the final uptake amount reaches 235.6 mL g–1 (c). The final uptake amount is equivalent to a total of 12 water molecules; i.e., the converted structure can uptake more water molecules than the number present in its mother compound. For 4, a type II adsorption is observed with a final uptake of ∼69.3 mL g–1. There is a certain interesting scenario with 5; it uptakes water up to P/P 0 ≈ 0.17 with a continuous rate of ∼61 mL g–1, equivalent to 2.1 water molecules, and then there is a change in the rate of adsorption, which ends at P/P 0 ≈ 0.35, of ∼85 mL g–1, equivalent to a total of three water molecules (c). Again a change of rate is observed and the final amount reaches ∼150.3 mL g–1 at P/P 0 ≈ 0.90, which is equivalent to ∼5 (5.2) molecules of water. No significant adsorption is observed for 6; the final amount is ∼38.6 mL g−1(c).

Luminescence Study

Optical properties of MOFs with d10 metal centers and recent successful use of them in various applications have brought them one more time under the spotlight of interest of researchers. Solid state photoluminescence study of the d10 complexes 1–6 and free respective ligands were performed at room temperature (). The ligand 3-bpdb and corresponding complexes 1 and 2 show emission maxima at 398 nm (λex = 255 nm), 405 nm (λex = 265 nm), and 408 nm (λex = 265 nm) respectively (a). Similar emission spectra is found for the 4-bpdb and its complexes 3 and 4. Complexes 3 and 4 exhibit emission maxima at 396 nm (λex = 255 nm) and 407 nm (λex = 265 nm) respectively and the ligand 4-bpdb at 394 nm (λex = 250 nm) (b). For the rest, ligand bpee shows emission spectra at 396 nm (λex = 260 nm) where its complexes 5 and 6 show emission maxima at 401 nm (λex = 260 nm) and 396 nm (λex = 250 nm) respectively (c).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Each fum and 4-bpdb bridges two Zn(II) centers, and the arrangement finally leads to large adamantane-like cages (b). In such an adamantane cage, Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distances through 4-bpdb and fum are ~15.4 and ~8.8 Å, respectively. These adamantoid cages are interconnected and extended to form a 3D diamondoid network with large hexagonal channels of a dimension about 18.9 × 14.4 Å2 (c). Topologically the framework can be presented as a 4-connected uninodal net with the Schläfli symbol {66} (f). Every diamondoid 3D network is interpenetrated with another four equivalent diamondoid networks to form a Class Ia 5-fold interpenetrated dimondoid network (e,f). Notably, the channels dimension is sufficiently decreased, and the overall 1D rectangular channels of dimension 9.6 × 7.3 Å2 along the b axis occur and guest water molecules reside in these channels (d). By PLATON the solvent-accessible void space of 4 was calculated and found as 27.5% of the total crystal volume.

Thermogravimetric Analysis (TG) and Powder X-ray Diffraction (PXRD) Study

To study the framework stability of the compounds 1-6, thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) studies are carried out. For both the studies a crystalline powder sample is used, and TGA has been carried out in the range of 25-650 °C (Figure S9). Single crystal analysis has shown that isostructural compounds 1 and 2 have no solvent molecule, and TGA is consistent with this; there is no significant weight loss up to ~200 °C for both of them, and then a steady decrease of weight loss was observed. Eventually, compound 3 shows a gradual weight loss with a step of 7.66% (40-80 °C), which corresponds to the escape of guest water molecules and the weight loss is equivalent to ~5 (4.88) water molecules. The desolvated framework is stable up to 150 °C, and after that it steadily disintegrates to unrecognized product. The TGA curve (Figure S9) of compound 4 shows there is no significant weight loss up to 90 °C, and then it starts a gradual weight loss with a step of 8.12% up to 190 °C, corresponding to ~2 water molecules. This dehydrated framework is stable up to 270 °C. Afterward it continuously dissociates to an unidentified product. TGA of 5 depicts that guest water molecules started to escape just after 40 °C and continuous up to 137 °C. A certain change in slope at ~137 °C indicates that guest molecules are completely removed from the system with a ~7% weight loss, which is equivalent to ~3 water molecules. Afterward with almost the same rate (but not equal) it dissociates to unrecognized products. From TGA it has been revealed that compound 6 shows a sharp weight loss with a step of 2.48% (60-90 °C), corresponding to the escape of one guest water molecule from the compound. This dehydrated framework is stable up to 370 °C with no significant weight loss. This is followed by a sharp weight loss, caused by an unrecognized product probably due to the decomposition of the frameworks.

However, the water adsorption shows enhancement of the amount of adsorption accompanied by some interesting phenomenon. The H2O adsorption profile for 3' exhibits a gate opening phenomenon; no uptake (~5 mL g-1) occurs at low pressure and then at P/P 0 ~ 0.422, a sharp rise takes place up to P/P 0 ~ 0.599, associated with an uptake of 207 mL g-1, and the final uptake amount reaches 235.6 mL g-1 (c). The final uptake amount is equivalent to a total of 12 water molecules; i.e., the converted structure can uptake more water molecules than the number present in its mother compound. For 4, a type II adsorption is observed with a final uptake of ~69.3 mL g-1. There is a certain interesting scenario with 5; it uptakes water up to P/P 0 ~ 0.17 with a continuous rate of ~61 mL g-1, equivalent to 2.1 water molecules, and then there is a change in the rate of adsorption, which ends at P/P 0 ~ 0.35, of ~85 mL g-1, equivalent to a total of three water molecules (c). Again a change of rate is observed and the final amount reaches ~150.3 mL g-1 at P/P 0 ~ 0.90, which is equivalent to ~5 (5.2) molecules of water. No significant adsorption is observed for 6; the final amount is ~38.6 mL g-1(c).

Luminescence Study

Optical properties of MOFs with d10 metal centers and recent successful use of them in various applications have brought them one more time under the spotlight of interest of researchers. Solid state photoluminescence study of the d10 complexes 1-6 and free respective ligands were performed at room temperature (). The ligand 3-bpdb and corresponding complexes 1 and 2 show emission maxima at 398 nm (λex = 255 nm), 405 nm (λex = 265 nm), and 408 nm (λex = 265 nm) respectively (a). Similar emission spectra is found for the 4-bpdb and its complexes 3 and 4. Complexes 3 and 4 exhibit emission maxima at 396 nm (λex = 255 nm) and 407 nm (λex = 265 nm) respectively and the ligand 4-bpdb at 394 nm (λex = 250 nm) (b). For the rest, ligand bpee shows emission spectra at 396 nm (λex = 260 nm) where its complexes 5 and 6 show emission maxima at 401 nm (λex = 260 nm) and 396 nm (λex = 250 nm) respectively (c).
